hints_html:
First find the cdf in terms of \(\theta\)

Recall the definition of the cumulative distribution function F of a continuous random variable with probability density function p:

\[\begin{aligned} F(\theta) = \int_{-\infty}^\theta p(t)\,dt\end{aligned}\]

Then use trigonometry to solve for x in terms of \(\theta\)

question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Solving first for the cdf in terms of \(\displaystyle \theta\), using that p(t) = 0 for t < -\(\pi\)/4, we have

\[\begin{aligned} F(\theta) &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\theta}\frac{2}{\pi}\,dt = \left.\frac{2}{\pi}t \right|_{-\pi/4}^{\theta} \\ &= \frac{2}{\pi}\left(\theta - \frac{-\pi}4\right)\end{aligned}\]

To find the cdf in terms of x we note that, from the diagram, \(\displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \tfrac{x}{2}\). Solving for \(\theta\) gives \(\displaystyle \theta = \arctan(\tfrac{x}{2})\) and thus we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F(x) = \frac2{\pi}\left(\arctan\left(\frac{x}{2}\right) + \frac{\pi}{4}\right)\end{aligned}\]

completing the problem.

statement_html:
Light Show on the Dance Floor

A laser is mounted 2m above the floor (see sketch) and its beam is directed along a straight line on the dance floor. For visual effects, the angle \(\theta\) changes periodically and randomly. The angle \(\theta\) is chosen uniformly in the interval \((-\frac{\pi}{4},\frac{\pi}{4})\), that is, the probability density function (pdf) is \(p(\theta) = \frac{2}{\pi}\) for \(-\frac{\pi}{4} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{4}\) and zero elsewhere.

Find the cumulative distribution function (cdf), F(x) of the x-coordinate of the laser point on the floor.
